title: How to Make Indian Bread

steps.headline: Dissolve the yeast in warm water.
steps.description: Place the warm water in a large bowl and sprinkle the yeast on top of it. Allow it to stand for 10 minutes, or until the mixture becomes somewhat foamy. If the mixture does not become foamy, it could mean that the yeast has died. Dead yeast will not be able to provide any lift for the dough, so you should discard it and start over with a new packet.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining dough ingredients.
steps.description: Add the sugar, milk, beaten egg, salt, and flour to the bowl. Mix well to combine into a soft dough. Add the flour gradually for best results. Once you have added enough flour to form the dough, stop and do not add any more, even if you have not yet used the full amount called for in the ingredient list.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Lightly flour a clean kitchen counter or working surface. Turn the dough out into the flour and knead, by hand, for 6 to 8 minutes or until it becomes smooth and elastic. You may also need to dust your hands with flour while kneading the dough to prevent it from sticking to your skin.

steps.headline: Let the dough rise for 1 hour.
steps.description: Lightly oil the sides of a large mixing bowl with vegetable oil or nonstick cooking spray. Place the dough inside this bowl, and cover the whole thing with a clean, damp dish towel. Set it in a warm location and let it rise until doubled in volume.

steps.headline: Knead in the garlic.
steps.description: Punch the dough down using your hands. Scatter the minced garlic over it, then knead firmly to distribute the garlic throughout the dough. The garlic is only optional. If you do not wish to add it, simply punch down the dough and do not worry about any additional kneading.

steps.headline: Separate into smaller portions.
steps.description: Break off a small ball of dough roughly 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) in diameter. Roll it between your hands until the ball becomes rounder and smoother, and place it on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Repeat with the rest of the dough. Note that you should keep at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space in between the dough when you arrange the portions on the baking sheet. The dough should have enough room to expand without the individual portions brushing into each other in the process.

steps.headline: Let rise before gently flattening.
steps.description: Cover the dough with a damp dish towel and allow it to rise for another 30 minutes, or until doubled in size again. Once risen, use a floured rolling pin to flatten each ball of dough into a circle less than 1-inch (2.5-cm) thick.

steps.headline: Grill the naan.
steps.description: If you intend to cook the naan on the grill, begin preheating it to high heat during the second rising period. Lightly oil the grill before putting the naan on it. Place a circle of naan on the prepared grill and cook for 2 to 3 minutes. It should become puffy, and the bottom should turn light brown in color. Brush the uncooked side of the naan with melted butter and flip the portion over. Brush the cooked side with butter, as well. Cook this second side for another 2 to 4 minutes, or until it also begins to brown. Remove the finished naan from the grill. Continue cooking the naan in this manner until all the dough has been used.

steps.headline: Alternatively, bake the naan.
steps.description: If you plan on baking the naan in the oven, preheat it to 500 degrees Fahrenheit (260 degrees Celsius) while the dough rises for a second time. Keep a baking stone or baking sheet in the oven as it preheats, so the stone is just as hot as the oven when you place the uncooked naan on it. Dip your hands in water and lightly wet each piece of dough. Place a few rounds of uncooked naan onto your preheated baking stone in a single layer. Do not let them touch or overlap. Bake for 4 to 5 minutes, or until the naan turns golden brown. Remove the finished naan from the oven and immediately brush with melted butter. Repeat until all the naan is cooked. Wait 3 to 4 minutes in between batches so that the baking stone has time to heat up again.

steps.headline: Enjoy.
steps.description: At this point, the naan is ready to eat. Serve it while still warm.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Combine the whole wheat flour, all-purpose flour, and salt in a large bowl, stirring them with a wooden mixing spoon until evenly mixed.

steps.headline: Gradually add the wet ingredients.
steps.description: Pour the olive oil into the flour and mix it in evenly using your mixing spoon. Gradually add the hot water, a little at a time, mixing well after each addition. Continue adding water until a soft dough forms. Note that the dough should be elastic yet not sticky. If the dough becomes too thick to mix with a spoon, begin mixing it with your hands.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Lightly flour a clean kitchen counter or similar working space. Turn the dough onto the floured counter and knead it by hand for 5 minutes or so, just until it becomes smooth. You may also need to dust your hands with flour to prevent them from sticking to the dough as you knead it.

steps.headline: Divide the dough into smaller portions.
steps.description: Separate the dough into 10 equal pieces and roll each portion into a ball using your hands. Set them aside to rest for 5 to 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Flatten the pieces out.
steps.description: Immediately before you are ready to cook the chapati, use a rolling pin dusted in flour to roll each ball of dough into a very thin circle, less than 1/4 inch (0.6 cm) thick. Note that you may need to reapply more flour to your working surface to prevent the dough from sticking as you roll it out.

steps.headline: Heat a skillet.
steps.description: Apply a thin coat of olive oil or cooking spray to a large skillet and heat the skillet on the stove for a few minutes on medium heat. The skillet will be hot enough to cook the chapati once you can see smoke rising from its surface.

steps.headline: Quickly cook the chapati in the skillet.
steps.description: Place one chapati in the hot skillet. Cook it for about 30 seconds, or until the underside has brown spots on it, then quickly flip it over to the other side. Cook the other side for another 30 seconds or so, until it, too, has brown spots on it. Remove the chapati from the skillet as soon as both sides are done. Repeat this process with all of the other dough circles.

steps.headline: Serve warm.
steps.description: Your batch of chapati is now ready to eat and enjoy.

steps.headline: Combine the flour, ghee, and salt.
steps.description: Place the three ingredients in a large mixing bowl and stir them together with a wooden mixing spoon until evenly combined.

steps.headline: Add the water.
steps.description: Add 1 to 2 Tbsp (15 to 30 ml) of water to the flour mixture and stir to moisten. Then, add another 1/2 cup (125 ml) of water and blend it in until a soft dough forms. Note that you may have difficulty mixing the dough with a spoon after you add the 1/2 cup (125 ml) of water. If this is the case, put the spoon down and begin mixing the dough with your hands.

steps.headline: Knead well.
steps.description: Lightly flour a clean kitchen counter. Turn the dough out onto the counter and knead it for 2 or 3 minutes, just long enough for the dough to become smooth. If your hands stick to the dough while you knead it, sprinkle a little flour onto the surface of the dough or dust your hands with flour. Do not add too much, though, since too much flour can cause the dough to crumble.

steps.headline: Let rest for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the dough with a clean, damp dish towel and allow it to rest at room temperature. This dough will not rise as much as a dough with yeast in it would rise, but the resting period does still allow the dough to settle and form air pockets.

steps.headline: Divide dough into even portions.
steps.description: Break off 2 to 3 inch (5 to 7.6 cm) portions of dough and roll them into balls. Arrange the dough on a parchment lined baking sheet, then cover them with a moist dish towel for a few minutes. A large plate would work just as well as a baking sheet here. You will not need the baking sheet to cook the bread. Instead, you only need something to place the uncooked dough on as it waits to be fried.

steps.headline: Roll the portions into flat circles.
steps.description: Apply a light coating of olive oil to the balls of dough. Use your hands or a lightly oiled rolling pin to roll them out to circles with a diameter 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) long. Place the dough back on your baking sheet or plate when done rolling it out.

steps.headline: Heat oil in a deep pan.
steps.description: Pour 1 inch (2.5 cm) of oil into a deep, heavy skillet. Warm it on the stove using high heat. The oil should reach a temperature of 350 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) before you move on to the next step. If you do not have a food-safe thermometer to use for checking oil temperatures, test the oil by dropping a small piece of dough in it. If the dough steadily rises to the surface of the oil, the oil is hot enough.

steps.headline: Fry the luchi.
steps.description: Gently place one circle of dough into the hot oil. After 1 to 2 minutes, or once the oil stops sizzling and the bottom side turns a deep cream color, gently turn the dough over and fry the other side for another minute or so. Each piece is done once both sides take on a golden-cream color. Remove the bread immediately after it finishes cooking. Repeat until all the circles of dough have been cooked. The bread should become puffy as it fries. You can enhance this effect by gently nudging the bread with a slotted spoon as it cooks in the oil.

steps.headline: Drain and serve.
steps.description: Remove each finished luchi from the oil using a slotted spoon and place them on a plate lined with clean paper towels. Let the excess oil drain off for a few minutes before eating and enjoying the luchi.

Allow it to stand for 10 minutes, or until the mixture becomes somewhat foamy. If the mixture does not become foamy, it could mean that the yeast has died. Dead yeast will not be able to provide any lift for the dough, so you should discard it and start over with a new packet. Stir in the remaining dough ingredients. Add the sugar, milk, beaten egg, salt, and flour to the bowl. Mix well to combine into a soft dough. Add the flour gradually for best results. Once you have added enough flour to form the dough, stop and do not add any more, even if you have not yet used the full amount called for in the ingredient list. Knead the dough. Lightly flour a clean kitchen counter or working surface. Turn the dough out into the flour and knead, by hand, for 6 to 8 minutes or until it becomes smooth and elastic. You may also need to dust your hands with flour while kneading the dough to prevent it from sticking to your skin. Let the dough rise for 1 hour. Lightly oil the sides of a large mixing bowl with vegetable oil or nonstick cooking spray. Place the dough inside this bowl, and cover the whole thing with a clean, damp dish towel. Set it in a warm location and let it rise until doubled in volume. Knead in the garlic. Punch the dough down using your hands. Scatter the minced garlic over it, then knead firmly to distribute the garlic throughout the dough. The garlic is only optional. If you do not wish to add it, simply punch down the dough and do not worry about any additional kneading. Separate into smaller portions. Break off a small ball of dough roughly 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) in diameter. Roll it between your hands until the ball becomes rounder and smoother, and place it on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Repeat with the rest of the dough. Note that you should keep at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space in between the dough when you arrange the portions on the baking sheet. Cover the dough with a damp dish towel and allow it to rise for another 30 minutes, or until doubled in size again. Once risen, use a floured rolling pin to flatten each ball of dough into a circle less than 1-inch (2.5-cm) thick. Grill the naan. If you intend to cook the naan on the grill, begin preheating it to high heat during the second rising period. Lightly oil the grill before putting the naan on it. Place a circle of naan on the prepared grill and cook for 2 to 3 minutes. It should become puffy, and the bottom should turn light brown in color. Brush the uncooked side of the naan with melted butter and flip the portion over. Brush the cooked side with butter, as well. Continue cooking the naan in this manner until all the dough has been used. Alternatively, bake the naan. If you plan on baking the naan in the oven, preheat it to 500 degrees Fahrenheit (260 degrees Celsius) while the dough rises for a second time. Keep a baking stone or baking sheet in the oven as it preheats, so the stone is just as hot as the oven when you place the uncooked naan on it. Wait 3 to 4 minutes in between batches so that the baking stone has time to heat up again. Enjoy. At this point, the naan is ready to eat. Serve it while still warm. sentences: The Naan Dissolve the yeast in warm water.
Place the warm water in a large bowl and sprinkle the yeast on top of it.
Allow it to stand for 10 minutes, or until the mixture becomes somewhat foamy.
If the mixture does not become foamy, it could mean that the yeast has died.
Dead yeast will not be able to provide any lift for the dough, so you should discard it and start over with a new packet.
Stir in the remaining dough ingredients.
Add the sugar, milk, beaten egg, salt, and flour to the bowl.
Mix well to combine into a soft dough.
Add the flour gradually for best results.
Once you have added enough flour to form the dough, stop and do not add any more, even if you have not yet used the full amount called for in the ingredient list.
Knead the dough.
Lightly flour a clean kitchen counter or working surface.
Turn the dough out into the flour and knead, by hand, for 6 to 8 minutes or until it becomes smooth and elastic.
You may also need to dust your hands with flour while kneading the dough to prevent it from sticking to your skin.
Let the dough rise for 1 hour.
Lightly oil the sides of a large mixing bowl with vegetable oil or nonstick cooking spray.
Place the dough inside this bowl, and cover the whole thing with a clean, damp dish towel.
Set it in a warm location and let it rise until doubled in volume.
Knead in the garlic.
Punch the dough down using your hands.
Scatter the minced garlic over it, then knead firmly to distribute the garlic throughout the dough.
The garlic is only optional.
If you do not wish to add it, simply punch down the dough and do not worry about any additional kneading.
Separate into smaller portions.
Break off a small ball of dough roughly 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) in diameter.
Roll it between your hands until the ball becomes rounder and smoother, and place it on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
Repeat with the rest of the dough.
Note that you should keep at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space in between the dough when you arrange the portions on the baking sheet.
The dough should have enough room to expand without the individual portions brushing into each other in the process.
Let rise before gently flattening.
Cover the dough with a damp dish towel and allow it to rise for another 30 minutes, or until doubled in size again.
Once risen, use a floured rolling pin to flatten each ball of dough into a circle less than 1-inch (2.5-cm) thick.
Grill the naan.
If you intend to cook the naan on the grill, begin preheating it to high heat during the second rising period.
Lightly oil the grill before putting the naan on it.
Place a circle of naan on the prepared grill and cook for 2 to 3 minutes.
It should become puffy, and the bottom should turn light brown in color.
Brush the uncooked side of the naan with melted butter and flip the portion over.
Brush the cooked side with butter, as well.
Cook this second side for another 2 to 4 minutes, or until it also begins to brown.
Remove the finished naan from the grill.
Continue cooking the naan in this manner until all the dough has been used.
Alternatively, bake the naan.
If you plan on baking the naan in the oven, preheat it to 500 degrees Fahrenheit (260 degrees Celsius) while the dough rises for a second time.
Keep a baking stone or baking sheet in the oven as it preheats, so the stone is just as hot as the oven when you place the uncooked naan on it.
Dip your hands in water and lightly wet each piece of dough.
Place a few rounds of uncooked naan onto your preheated baking stone in a single layer.
Do not let them touch or overlap.
Bake for 4 to 5 minutes, or until the naan turns golden brown.
Remove the finished naan from the oven and immediately brush with melted butter.
Repeat until all the naan is cooked.
Wait 3 to 4 minutes in between batches so that the baking stone has time to heat up again.
Enjoy.
At this point, the naan is ready to eat.
Serve it while still warm.
The Chapati Mix the dry ingredients.
Combine the whole wheat flour, all-purpose flour, and salt in a large bowl, stirring them with a wooden mixing spoon until evenly mixed.
Gradually add the wet ingredients.
Pour the olive oil into the flour and mix it in evenly using your mixing spoon.
Gradually add the hot water, a little at a time, mixing well after each addition.
Continue adding water until a soft dough forms.

If the dough becomes too thick to mix with a spoon, begin mixing it with your hands.
